title: Ticket #1098: Inconsistent treatment of undefined periodic expressions
description:
When PeriodicHold=undefined, the schedd ignores it. The GridManager, JobRouter, and shadow, on the hand, all put the job on hold with something like the following hold reason (taken from an example where it was the GridManager that did it). "The UNKNOWN (never set) PeriodicHold expression '' evaluated to UNDEFINED"

This inconsistency made it hard to understand behavior observed by Brian Bockelman in his submission of grid universe jobs.

In my opinion, two things should be fixed:

  1. the schedd should put jobs on hold when periodic expressions are undefined

  2. the hold reason should be less confusing

In the GridManager, the responsible code is in basejob.cpp: 

    case UNDEFINED_EVAL:
	JobHeld( reason.Value() );
        SetEvaluateState();
	break;

JobRouter.cpp: 

        case UNDEFINED_EVAL:
            ret_val = SetJobHeld(job->src_ad, reason.Value());
            break;

In shadow_user_policy.cpp: 

    case UNDEFINED_EVAL:
            /*
               If a given policy expression was undefined, the user
               screwed something up and they better deal with it.  We
               don't just want the job to leave the queue...
            */
        shadow->holdJob( reason.Value(), CONDOR_HOLD_CODE_JobPolicyUndefined, 0\
 );
   	break;
remarks:
2010-Jan-08 17:22:39 by matt:
Similar problems have been seen with WANT_SUSPEND, see #1001.

I think UNDEFINED should mean False/ignore, which has the nice bonus of not requiring all jobs to have all policy expressions defined.

A set of functions for extracting policy consistently across the code base seems even more useful now that this has been hit on the job policy side as well.
